entry.title: How to fix npm error notarget @sap/hdi-deploy when you create a CAP app in BAS
entry.content:
Update (July 2025): Good news ‚Äî @sap/hdi-deploy@5.5.0 is now available on npm, so this specific error may have disappeared.
But keep reading! The root cause ‚Äî a dependency pointing to a version that isn‚Äôt published yet‚Äîcan happen again with future releases. The steps below show how to unblock yourself whenever npm throws a notarget error for an @sap/hdi-deploy package.

 

When do you see this error?

1. In SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) click File ‚Üí New Project from Template.

2. Choose CAP Project and fill in the project name, runtime (Node.js), database (HANA Cloud), etc.

3. Open the terminal and run:

cds add mta   # create files for Cloud Foundry / Kyma deploy
npm i         # install dependencies‚Äã

4. npm i stops with this message:

npm error code ETARGET
npm error notarget No matching version found for @sap/hdi-deploy@5.5.0.‚Äã

Even if you force "@SAP/hdi-deploy": "5.4.2" in package.json, the error still appears.

 

Why does it happen?

cds add mta adds this line to devDependencies:

"@sap/cds-dk": ">=8"

@SAP/cds-dk version 8.x asks for @SAP/hdi-deploy@5.5.0, but 5.5.0 is not yet published on npm. So npm cannot find it and throws ETARGET.

 

The 3‚Äëline fix

1.  (Optional) clean old modules and cache:

rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm cache clean --force

2. Install the latest cds-dk (today it is 9.1.3):

npm install -D @sap/cds-dk@latest

3. Install the rest:

npm install

cds-dk 9.x points to @sap/hdi-deploy 5.4.2, which exists, so the install succeeds.

 

Example package.json

{
  "scripts": {
    "start": "cds run"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@sap/cds": "^7",
    "@sap/hana-client": "^2",
    "@sap/xssec": "^3"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@sap/cds-dk": "^9.1.3"
  }
}

 

More Information

SAP Community Q&A (same issue): https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/generate-cap-project-in-bas-with-error-sap-hdi-deploy-5-4-2-not-match/qaq-p/14062673

 

Wrap‚Äëup

Next time you hit the @sap/hdi-deploy notarget error, just remember: upgrade @sap/cds-dk and you are done.

If this post helped you, please give Kudos and leave a comment! üôå

entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, that‚Äôs all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAP‚Äôs commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.

entry.title: Anna Hartmann
entry.content:
Anna

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Anna on LinkedIn

Anna is managing director at in4MD Service GmbH. Her journey began with mastering ABAP programming from 2010 to 2013. By 2013, Anna was deeply involved in the HANA environment, managing around 100 databases and developing teaching materials covering areas such as Predictive Analysis Library, Geospatial, Text Mining, Fiori development on HANA, and Smart Data Integration for the SAP University Alliance Program in the SAP University Competence Center Magdeburg. This extensive engagement has equipped her with an in-depth knowledge of the entire HANA platform, both 1.0 and 2.0. Anna is also one of the authors of the SAP Press book "SAP HANA ‚Äì Datenbankadministration" (ISBN 978-3-8362-6850-9).

Topics of interest: HANA database, HANA Cloud, SAP landscape and architecture, ABAP, BTP

Anna, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

What drives Anna is ensuring the needs of mid-sized customers are met, as they often feel overlooked by SAP. Anna is passionate about being their voice, representing their interests whether through on-premise solutions, cloud (Azure, Google), or RISE and GROW projects. Her diverse background and commitment to these clients makes her an ideal candidate for the SAP Mentor Program, where I can advocate effectively for this crucial segment of the SAP community. Anna also has a broad network within the technical SAP community thanks to the many years of involvement in DSAG.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Get involved into the SAP community, it's a great opportunity to learn from others and gain different perspectives. Stay curious and continuously learn about new SAP technologies and best practices. Network actively with other SAP professionals to share insights and solve challenges together. Always keep the core business processes of your company or customer in mind to deliver real value with your technical solutions.

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, it‚Äôs time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025‚Äôs Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Is‚Ä¶ PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform ‚ÄúLegal Ease‚Äù. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. ‚ÄúLegal Ease‚Äù enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: ‚ÄúLegal Ease‚Äù addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let‚Äôs not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and What‚Äôs Next

The Hackathon‚Äôs main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

‚ÄúIt is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we‚Äôve seen incredible progress and innovation.‚Äù

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I‚Äôd love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Streamlining REST API Integrations in SAP Datasphere with Task Chains and FastAPI on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction 

With the recent introduction of API Tasks in Task Chains, SAP Datasphere now supports direct orchestration of external REST services (see SAP documentation). This enhancement unlocks new integration possibilities, particularly for scenarios where no standard connectors are available. 

In our use case, we aim to extract data from an open REST API and load it into SAP Datasphere. To achieve this, we developed a custom wrapper API‚Äîbuilt with FastAPI and hosted on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)‚Äîthat handles both data extraction and the writing of that data into SAP HANA Cloud, which underlies SAP Datasphere. The entire data loading process is then triggered and managed via a REST API step within a Task Chain. 

At the core of this solution is a lightweight microservice that seamlessly integrates a third-party REST API into SAP Datasphere. The microservice is designed to be modular, secure, and easy to maintain, and enables a fully automated integration pipeline. 

Key Features of the Approach 

  • REST API extraction wrapped in a FastAPI-based microservice 
  • Basic HTTP Authentication for secure access 
  • Data retrieval from public or external REST APIs 
  • Automatic detection and mapping of SAP HANA-compatible data types 
  • Dynamic table creation in SAP HANA Cloud 
  • Batch data insertion with upload timestamps for traceability 
  • Deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) 
  • Registration as an HTTP connection in SAP Datasphere 
  • Integration into a Task Chain for full orchestration of the data workflow 

 

 

Requirement 

Data integration from 3rd-party REST APIs is still a challenge in SAP Datasphere, particularly when no standard connectors are available. SAP offers solutions like Open Connectors or SAP Cloud Integration via the Integration Suite. However, these options come with additional cost and infrastructure overhead. 

Our proposed solution is a lightweight, developer-friendly alternative that utilizes: 

  • A simple REST service hosted on SAP BTP 
  • Open SQL schema access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud instance 
  • Integration into Task Chains via the new REST API task type 

This allows full orchestration and governance from within SAP Datasphere, without introducing unnecessary middleware layers. 

Solution 

FastAPI Solution on SAP BTP 

At the core of this architecture lies a microservice built with FastAPI. This Python-based service acts as a universal adapter to extract, transform (lightly), and load data into SAP HANA Cloud. The code can also be found in our GIT repository. 

Key Components 

  1. Authentication 
    All secure endpoints require HTTP Basic Authentication, with credentials configurable via environment variables. 
  2. HANA Integration 
    1. Using the hana_ml library, the service connects to the HANA Cloud database and  
      automatically detects column types using heuristics (e.g., timestamp recognition, length-adjusted NVARCHAR) 
    2. Dynamically creates a table if it doesn't exist 
    3. Inserts records in batch mode, with an added UPLOAD_TS timestamp column 

  3. Endpoints

    Endpoint 

    Method 

    Description 

    / 

    GET 

    Health check 

    /test-hana-connection 

    GET 

    Verifies database credentials and connection 

    /extract-and-write 

    POST 

    Triggers extraction from a third-party API and writes to HANA 

    /preview-data 

    GET 

    Fetches sample records from a REST API 

    /infer-types 

    GET 

    Infers HANA-compatible types from JSON response 

  4. Deployment 
    The service is packaged with a manifest.yaml for deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry). It uses the Python buildpack and runs via uvicorn in production. 
     

Outlook 

This FastAPI-based solution can be flexibly extended to support more advanced integration needs: 

  • Authentication: Easily add OAuth2, API keys, or Bearer tokens to handle secured APIs. 
  • REST Call Chaining: Implement multi-step workflows by chaining dependent API calls asynchronously. 
  • Pagination: Add logic for offset, cursor, or token-based pagination to collect full datasets. 
  • Schema Flexibility: Support field renaming, normalization of nested JSON, and custom type overrides. 

Testing 

For Testing purposes we tested everything with Postman and the public available Harry Potter API https://hp-api.onrender.com. 

SAP Datasphere Integration 

To communicate with this BTP service we performed the following steps: 

  1. Whitelist the IPs of our BTP instance in the SAP Datasphere tenant (For testing from Business Application Studio (BAS)you may also want to whitelist those IPs as well) 
  2. Create a HTTP connection for the usage in the Task Chain 

     

     

In the task chain we can now add this step and configure the body. 

 

 

In the Configuration panel we can now select our HTTP connection: 

 

 

And also configure our REST call: 

After running the Task Chain we can see the data is now loaded into our table. 

 

Conclusion 

The integration of a FastAPI-based microservice into SAP Datasphere via Task Chains marks a significant advancement in streamlining data ingestion from third-party REST APIs. By leveraging SAP BTP for deployment and utilizing the new REST API task type within Task Chains, we demonstrated a lightweight and developer-friendly alternative to traditional integration tools like SAP Cloud Integration or Open Connectors. 

Looking ahead, the framework can be extended to accommodate more complex data workflows, robust security models, and advanced transformation logic. With this foundation, organizations can seamlessly orchestrate external data services within SAP Datasphere while maintaining full control, traceability, and governance‚Äîall without the need for additional middleware.

entry.title: Why an organisation should always strive to keep a clean core in all transformation projects
entry.content:
What is a transformation Journey and why would a business choose to begin one?

There are many issues faced by businesses today in the ever-continuing goal to become ‚Äòbest run‚Äô. Some of these issues include natural disasters, geopolitical tensions such as tariffs, wars and other events that previously were once in a lifetime events, these are now the new common challenges of businesses in the modern age. Any one of these challenges or multiple of them combined can prompt a business to embark on a transformation journey.

An Enterprise small or big who wishes to unlock the full potential of their business in any sort of business landscape must leverage information technology as an important tooling. In a partnership with SAP, this enterprise can employ a guided transformation journey such as RISE with SAP. A transformation journey can be intimidating but with guided transformation journeys like RISE, the process can be simplified. [1]

Some motivations for the transformation could include:

  1. The Increasing Disruption of Global Supply Chains:
    Global supply chains are increasingly vulnerable to disruptions that highlight the critical need for resilience, agility, and the ability to adapt quickly. Events such as the EverGiven ship blockage in the Suez Canal illustrate how a single incident can unravel an entire organization crippling production schedules, depleting inventory levels, and significantly impacting customer satisfaction.
  2. Challenges in Meeting Evolving Customer Expectations:
    Modern businesses face a paradigm shift in managing customer expectations. The era of simple B2C (business-to-consumer) engagements has evolved into consumers demanding personalized solutions tailored to their specific needs. Additionally, customers expect businesses to prioritize sustainability and adhere to ethical practices, requiring organizations to be agile and responsive to changing societal demands. it is not enough for a business to simply sell shoes or clothes anymore. They need to ensure ethical sourcing and reduced carbon footprint for there entire chain of business.
  3. The Pressure to Keep Pace with Technological Advancements:
    Rapid technological advancements are transforming industries across the globe. Businesses must embrace innovation to stay competitive. whether that involves adopting AI-driven insights, enabling real-time data analysis, or leveraging automation to streamline operations. Falling behind in technology adoption not only puts companies at a disadvantage but can also limit their ability to innovate and scale efficiently.
  1. Some additional motivations for customers who undergo a transformation journey such as rise with sap could include the need for real time insights into their business, increasing the robustness and responsiveness of their systems, increased cloud flexibility and ability to maneuver operations to take advantage of new opportunities or to avoid potential downfalls.

Due to these challenges and new business opportunities a business might decide to embark on a transformation journey; from an old ERP System to a newer one in efforts to take advantage of the benefits of the cloud such as increased agility and ability to scale. [2] New modern comprehensive packages like S4HANA Cloud can provide this.  In this transformation journey, an important choice must be made. The choice is whether to opt for a brand-new implementation (greenfield) or a system conversion (‚Äúbrownfield‚Äù) implementation strategy. [3] The challenges in keeping the core clean in these two implementation strategies are different.  [4]

While these benefits can be realized from a transformation process, they can be undermined by the negative effects that may arise if the customer fails to prioritize maintaining a clean core. Keeping the core processes clean and free of irrelevant customizations reduces technical debt, improved business adaptability and enables more agile businesses are key principles that define the importance of clean core. [5]

 

What is the clean core strategy and why is it necessary?

From the dawn of Enterprise Resource Planning ‚ÄúKeeping the core clean‚Äù has always been a goal. Although most businesses might believe they are completely different in terms of business structure or complexity, enterprise resource planning [6]

Clean core simply represents the ERP system without any baggage such as layers and layers of custom code, it means keeping your ERP System close to SAP Defined standard as much as possible while handling the integrations of extensions and modifications through SAP Defined best practices.  [5]. Clean means Up to date, transparent, unmodified, consistent, efficient and cloud compliant, Core means the main aspects of an ERP system landscape, the extensibility, data, integration and processes. [7]

Following a clean core strategy includes the active efforts to reduce data and process inconsistencies, establish suitable housekeeping processes and governance structures, maximizing the use of SAP‚Äôs standard functionality and minimizing the complexity of customization [7]

 

SAP‚ÄôS Clean Core Approach.

A business operating at its optimal core will have an up-to-date system with cloud-compliant extensions and seamless integration. SAP for a long time has offered extensive capabilities for its software to be extended primarily through ABAP. Businesses were able to tailor the software to their specific market needs. However this freedom to customize however lead to significant long-term challenges that were expensive both financially and in terms of time. Customers who frequently customize functionality to align with a specific process result in the creation of thousands of custom objects, often lacking proper governance and documentation.

This technical debt can result in security vulnerabilities, degraded performance, and widespread system instability, making upgrades and transformations costly, complex, and time-consuming, effectively trapping companies in outdated software. Clean core emerged as a response to these challenges, addressing past architectural limitations by shifting from ‚Äúin-core‚Äù ABAP customization to low-code, no-code, pro-code, and side-by-side solutions available on SAP BTP. [9]

 

 

Clean Core and its benefits during and after a transformation project.

There are multiple approaches to applying a clean core transformation; In a greenfield scenario, we can start from fresh and adopt a clean core from the beginning. This approach enables us to get all the key benefits of clean core right out of the box. On the contrary, however, a brownfield approach allows the new instance to maintain some of the old instance‚Äôs complexities and possibly unwanted customizations. In this scenario we must embark on a journey to get the core to become clean.  

Businesses may adopt a brownfield approach when existing processes are too complex or costly to restart, opting instead to preserve core operations. Yet even in these cases, maintaining a clean core is critical. A CTO evaluating the effort will inevitably ask: what is in it for us with clean core?

Keeping a clean core at heart implies a minimization of the need for custom code. Which directly translates into lower maintenance cost. This approach will reduce the total cost of ownership due to reducing maintenance. Also, technical debt which is the accrued cost of past fixes and nonstandard implementations, will also be a significant drain on the budget of an IT department saddled with an unclean core after a brownfield project is complete. [8]  

By working towards a clean core, organizations might begin to see a reduction in the total cost of ownership of the software and the ability to deploy its resources towards newer business issues rather than trying to solve the problem that comes from an accrual of technical debt. Keeping to the clean core emphasis on standard functionality helps in the development of a more robust and predictable system which directly enhances user productivity and satisfaction.

Keeping a clean core can enable more swifter updates. Some firms have reported cutting upgrade timelines by as much as 40%., traditionally as any large business who has implemented an ERP Solution will tell you upgrades are slow, and extremely expensive. Clean core changes this dynamic by decoupling custom logic which enables businesses to consume SAP‚Äôs Innovation rapidly. [8]

Having a clean core could also leave a business better equipped to handle various regulation and security standards. A clean core environment is easier to monitor as there are now clearer boundaries between the core ERP System. Reduced complexity will also lead to a higher level of security as fewer entry points are now present within the system. [8]

To support the clean core journey SAP, a strong advocate of maintaining a clean core both during and after a transformation provide instruments to enable the achievement and sustenance of clean core. In a clean core architected environment as recommended, the architectural approach as provided by sap supports the extension of features through well-defined public APIs, Business events which is a system generated notification in the ERP that something has occurred eg: a purchase order has been approved, or a goods movement has been posted.  [4]

External applications can subscribe to the event and trigger processes or workflows. This new approach by SAP removes the need for modifying the core of the software allowing for loose coupling. It enables businesses to react to change in real time without the need to modify the ERP of the software.

This approach means it is now easier to swap out, update or add new functionality with minimal disruption enabling the workforce to take advantage at any key moment of the new benefits offered by the cloud environment after a transformation project to S4HANA.

Beyond technical best practices the SAP clean core strategy of enabling teams to extend the system alongside the core rather than modifying it directly provides more room to build, test, and iterate without compromising stability. For example, one SAP customer experienced a four-month delay during a scheduled rollout due to dependencies tied to their legacy Z-code. Such delays can be costly in time, money, and momentum. By reducing reliance on core modifications, clean core emphasizes modular development, where individual components contribute to overall system agility.

Achieving and Sustaining Clean Core after the transformation project

 

 

The main goals to maintain clean core after the transformation.

Since our organizational goal is to achieve and maintain a clean core, it is essential to define the key components and indicators of a clean core, as well as the practices required to preserve it.

  1. Clean Extensions
  2. Clean Business Processes
  3. Clean Data

Clean Extensions: After the transformation journey is completed, a business need or requirement might provide a situation in which the business needs to add extensions to their ERP Systems. Extensions could help to meet various needs while providing immense value; but in order not to ruin the efforts we have undertaken so far to keep the core clean; it is important that we ensure they are implemented in a clean core compliant manner.

S4HANA is feature-rich, so organizations should critically assess the need for extensions before creating them, as the required functionality may already be available through SAP BTP. Extensions must be designed to support seamless ERP upgrades, avoiding risks or disruptions. Development teams should fully understand the requirements before starting and determine whether an extension should be implemented on-stack or side-by-side. Classical extension techniques are strongly discouraged, as they increase the likelihood of system instability, upgrade failures, and higher maintenance costs.

If, after evaluating all features, a business still requires extensions to meet its objectives, they should be implemented either internally within S4HANA Cloud as on-stack extensions or externally as side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP. SAP‚Äôs ABAP Cloud Development Model (CDM) enforces the use of released APIs and applies syntax checks to ensure compliance.

Keeping extensions clean is essential because poorly designed or non-compliant extensions can cause upgrade delays, break business-critical processes, introduce security vulnerabilities, and significantly increase long-term maintenance overhead. By minimizing unnecessary extensions, ensuring compliance with cloud standards, and aligning with customer requirements, organizations can maximize ERP effectiveness while maintaining a clean core.

 

Diagram of clean core extensibility with BTP.

Clean Business Processes: Organizations aiming to maintain a clean core must establish a strong organizational structure with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. This structure, combined with the selection of scalable, secure technological tools, forms the foundation for maintaining clean processes. During and after the transformation, tools such as Signavio Process Manager and Signavio Process Governance enhance process visibility, improve internal compliance, and accelerate business process optimization. [11]

By leveraging these solutions within a clean core environment, businesses can better understand their processes, identify root causes of issues more easily, and reduce both transformation time and risk outcomes that are far harder to achieve without a clean process core. Well-documented, efficient processes also help organizations remain competitive in a fast-paced business environment, ultimately leading to stronger results.

Clean Data: In the cloud and digital age, clean, usable data is one of the most valuable assets for organizations, enabling faster decision-making and actionable insights. Following a transformation to S4HANA Cloud, businesses gain a robust platform for managing, processing, and applying data effectively.

However, data is only as valuable as the processes and principles that ensure its cleanliness. The three main pillars of clean data are:

  • Accuracy: Data must reflect the true state of the business. Without proper validation rules, regular quality checks, and governance, inaccurate data can lead to faulty decisions, inefficient processes, and reduced user trust. Regular audits and automated checks help prevent these issues.
  • Completeness: Incomplete data undermines decision-making and trust. Businesses should enforce standardized data entry, validation processes, and comprehensive collection practices to maintain completeness.
  • Consistency: Data must be uniform across systems. Inconsistencies create confusion, errors, and inefficiencies. Maintaining standards, conducting profiling, and implementing integration and reconciliation processes are critical to consistency. [4]

Maintaining a clean core with respect to data maximizes the value derived from data, enhances process efficiency, and reduces total cost of ownership by enabling efficient management of data volumes and reliable results from business processes.

Conclusion

Regardless of the motivations for a transformation journey, maintaining a clean core during and after the process delivers significant organizational value. Beyond reducing total cost of ownership, a clean core enables the adoption of the latest innovations a critical advantage in the AI-driven era and provides the flexibility to meet evolving business objectives.

The five pillars of clean core represent more than a technological change; they signify a mindset and paradigm shift from on-premise to cloud-based systems. This shift affects custom code, data, processes, and overall business operations, keeping them effective and efficient.

When combined with a transformation initiative, a clean core unlocks a new operational paradigm, maximizing business potential and supporting the development of a sustainable, best-run enterprise. Given these combined benefits, it is clear that maintaining a clean core during a transformation journey is in the best interest of any organization.

Find the Github for this project here

Introduction: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the ability to process written language like English or other languages and convert it into a format that computers can understand. SQL (Structured Query Language) is a language used to manage and manipulate data within a database system.

SQL has a limited set of operations, making it syntactically simple and easy to learn. This also makes it easier for large language models to generate accurate SQL queries, unlike programming languages like Java, which offer many ways to accomplish the same task.

Natural Language to SQL (NL2SQL) provides an interface that allows non-technical users to interact with databases, explore data, and gather insights without prior SQL knowledge. While a basic understanding of SQL is not required, it is beneficial, as it helps users phrase queries more accurately and obtain better results from the system.

Users who rarely interact with databases no longer need to manually write complex queries. They can simply communicate with the bot and receive accurate responses. Implementing an NL2SQL system saves time and provides a faster, more efficient way to generate real business insights.

Prerequisites for Building This:

  • A working Python environment
  • HANA Cloud
  • AI Core on BTP
  • A dataset to query (for this example, the Spotify listening history dataset from Kaggle)
  • Streamlit to create a chat-style interface for querying the database

My Dataset

 

These are the descriptions of some of the data contained in my dataset. you can find the dataset here, however compared to a real world database; this database is simple and does not have any of the following complications that make a NL2SQL implementation difficult.

  • In a real world scenario the same data can be formatted in many different ways. Sex can be represented as Male, male or M. Different locations have different ways of representing digits eg: 1,000 vs 1.000.
  • If the LLM Lack the domain specific understanding it could misunderstand the user queries.
  • SQL IS Strict with its syntax like every other programming language. if the generated code does not match its strict syntax rules it will fail.
  • Questions can be ambigous and this is why a standard knowledge of SQL is ideal to make this solution work. a simple question about ‚ÄòWho is the most popular artist‚Äô can elicit responses such as total minutes played, or who was skipped the least etc.

To address these challenges, we can implement a prompt engineering approach where questions are classified by complexity. More complex questions are checked for ambiguity, and vector embeddings are used to generate accurate and reliable responses.

When a user asks a question, we collect high-quality question/SQL pairs and store them in HANA. The more the system is used, the better it becomes at generating SQL statements. For new questions, vector embeddings are created and searched against the database of existing solutions to find the most relevant response.

But for now this is a basic implementation of the system.

The first step is to create a database schema. this just shows the initial relationship between the tables, how the data can be stored and the columns.
I created this table and my schema in my HANA database as follows, hanas columnar based storage might make it differ from yours if you use another database.

ts TIMESTAMP NOT NULL,
platform NVARCHAR(50),

track_name NVARCHAR(255),
artist_name NVARCHAR(255),
album_name NVARCHAR(255),
reason_start NVARCHAR(100),
reason_end NVARCHAR(100),
shuffle BOOLEAN,
skipped BOOLEAN
);

I then uploaded my data to hana. Usually a large data source like this wont be manually uploaded but would be gathered from many places into one centralized location to be queried.

 

Importing initial components

Pandas is a library used for working with datasets, HDBCLI is the python interface for working with the HANA Cloud Database.

To access your HANA Database, you will need three important pieces of information. your database Username, your database password and the host vector. I stored mine in an env file
It should look something like this

HANA_HOST_VECTOR=‚Äò***********.prodeu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com‚Äô

Hare Krishna üôè I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

This blog explores the strategic advantages of moving to HANA Cloud, real-world scenarios, migration approaches, and how businesses can leverage this transformation for long-term success üåü.

SAP HANA on-premise has been the backbone of enterprise IT for over a decade. But today, companies face challenges like:

  • üìâDifficulty scaling for seasonal or global demand

2. A Real-World Story: Fashion Retailer Migrating During Peak Season

A large fashion retailer running ECC on HANA on-premise faced challenges during peak shopping seasons:

  • üíæHardware was over-provisioned to handle peak loads but under-utilized the rest of the year

By migrating to SAP HANA Cloud, the retailer was able to:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èScale compute resources elastically during high-demand weeks, then scale down during off-season

  • üìäIntegrate sales, inventory, and supply chain data in SAP Datasphere for real-time visibility

  • üí∞Reduce infrastructure costs by 25‚Äì30% while improving system performance

3.üõ†Ô∏è‚ö° Migration Approach: Self-Service Tools for a Smooth Transition

2Ô∏è‚É£Execution with SAP Self-Service Migration Tools

  • üõ†Ô∏è Self-service migration: Provides a guided, wizard-based process for migrating data from on-premise HANA or BTP HANA Service to HANA Cloud.

  • ‚ö°Supports multiple migration scenarios:

5. Migration Challenges & How to Overcome Them

While migrating to SAP HANA Cloud brings huge benefits, enterprises may face some challenges. Here‚Äôs what to watch for:

  • üõ†Ô∏è Custom ABAP Code & Extensions

    • Custom programs may have compatibility issues with HANA Cloud.

    • Mitigation: Test custom code in sandbox or trial HANA Cloud before cutover.

  • ‚ö°Application & Integration Dependencies

    • Connected apps or BI tools need retargeting.

    • Mitigation: Rebind or redirect connections to HANA Cloud and Datasphere endpoints.

  • ‚è±Ô∏è Downtime & Cutover Planning

    • Minimizing business disruption is critical.

    • Mitigation: Plan cutover during off-peak periods, validate all delta loads, and communicate with stakeholders.

6. How This Fits with RISE & GROW with SAP

  • üåüRISE with SAP ‚Üí Migration is a natural step for existing ERP customers moving to S/4HANA Cloud

  • üå±GROW with SAP ‚Üí Net-new cloud ERP customers start directly on HANA Cloud and benefit from innovation immediately

7. Business Outcomes After Migration

  • ‚ö°Faster innovation cycles with ML, JSON, graph, and Datasphere integration

  • üåêGlobal reach through geo-replication

  • üõ°Ô∏è Operational resilience with automated HA and backups

8. Future Roadmap / Innovation After Migration

After migration, enterprises can unlock new business capabilities on HANA Cloud:

  • ü§ñMachine Learning & Predictive Analytics

  • üõ†Ô∏è Automation & RPA

    • Automate repetitive processes and alerts for faster operational response.

  • üöÄFuture-Ready ERP

    • Smooth path to S/4HANA Cloud or advanced SAP solutions under RISE with SAP.

Key Takeaways

  • üöÄMigration to SAP HANA Cloud is strategic, not just technical

  • üõ†Ô∏è Start with analytics or sandbox workloads first

  • üñ•Ô∏è Use SAP guides + Enable Now simulation to de-risk projects

  • üåüAlign migration with your RISE roadmap for long-term gains

entry.title: Give your Joule Agents ü§ñ the gift of Memory üí≠, with Hana Cloud ‚ú®
entry.content:
When Joule agents can write/read memories in SAP HANA Cloud, they:

  • Remember business facts at scale (supplier habits, contract quirks, SLA exceptions) ‚úÖ

  • Retrieve them fast & accurately with HANA Cloud Vector Engine ‚ö°

  • Keep memories human-readable, sortable, and dead-simple to implement üß©

That means fewer repeated mistakes, smarter suggestions, and agents that actually learn with your business over time.

An example of some memories for an invoice exception agent.
You can make them as detailed or a simple as you want in the agent prompt!

 

 

How it works

  1. A simple ‚ÄúMemories‚Äù table

    Human-readable text + metadata (who/what it‚Äôs about, when learned, importance, TTL, etc.).

    Optional: a vector column for semantic search.

  2. Vector search for recall

    Store an embedding of each memory ‚Üí use approximate nearest neighbor (ANN) to fetch the right facts instantly (‚ÄúWhich supplier often uses expired POs?‚Äù). BM25 or other strategies are available. I love BM25's reliability for same-language and same-topic knowledge meshes.

  3. One tool your agent calls

    Add a tool (below) so your agent can append or update memories whenever it learns something new.

  4. Update the Agent prompt to have it use the memory well!

           Something like:

Before answering, search (memory.search_hana) with a concise query (supplier/invoice/PO terms; limit top_k‚â§8); 
use the results to tailor your response. 
Only write when you learn a new, stable, factual business detail; 
upsert (memory.upsert_hana) instead of inserting duplicates‚Äîtreat as duplicate if normalized context matches or vector similarity ‚â•0.86 and the same entity (supplier/invoice/PO) is involved; 
if duplicate, refresh last_seen_at (and occurrence_count if available). Format memories as one dense sentence in context 
(e.g., YYYY-MM-DD | INV-XXXX | Supplier ABC | PO 4500001123 | 4,980.00 EUR | expired PO used) 
and a brief actionable description; keep context ‚â§220 chars, use present tense. 
Set importance 1‚Äì5 (5 = critical risk) and ttl_days (low importance decays, 0 = never expires). 
Do not store ephemeral chatter or sensitive data; prefer patterns over one-offs. 
If you update or add a memory, mention it briefly to the user; otherwise be concise and never dump full tables unless asked.

 

Add two memory tools (Joule Skills)

"Add Memory" is a simple SQL Write

"Retrieve Memory" is a simple SQL Read, with semantic search (BM25+Embeddings)

 

 

Advanced memory patterns (that HANA makes easy) üöÄ

  • Disappearing memories (decay/TTL): small quirks fade unless they‚Äôre re-observed.

  • Hierarchical memories: supplier-site ‚Üí supplier ‚Üí region ‚Üí global policy.

  • World representations: keep a simple graph of relationships (supplier‚Üîplant, approver‚Üîcost center), or materialize views for fast joins.

  • Learning from mistakes: tag memories with resolution outcome so the agent prefers strategies that worked.

 

Result:

A living, human-readable knowledge fabric your Joule agents can trust.
It's fast, explainable, and always improving. ‚ú®

entry.title: Simplifying Field Service with AI in SAP FSM
entry.content:
Introduction:

SAP field service management operations set up for any new company settings requires careful planning, which has become much easier with the help of built in cloud AI features. With the help of these smart tools companies in FSM helps with much better decision making. Which also helps the technicians to complete their work more efficiently since they will be getting real-time support, faster & for instance access to the information which they require and smart scheduling. This results in lesser delays, and much improved service quality.

 Prerequisites for SAP Cloud FSM:

  • Must have a valid license for SAP AI Units.
  • Premium AI features must be activated in FSM tenant.
  • Sufficient Historical Data (1000 activities with the execution Stage should be equal to CLOSE status in order to train the system)


Key AI Features in SAP FSM:

Below is the breakdown of the core AI functionalities available

1. Intelligent Filtering

  1. Assignment Duration Prediction
  2. Activity Summary
  3. Equipment Summary

 

-> Intelligent Filtering:

Intelligent Filtering will help by showing the most relevant technicians only for the job and automatically sorting. which is like having a smart assistant that understands the input. Instead of checking each customer manually system will sort them based on the requirements of the job, then you will be getting a list of customers who passed the requirements which leads to lesser time consumption and better accuracy.
For example, imagine you're a dispatcher in FSM who is trying to assign a technician to a service job, you have list of technicians, but not all of them are suitable for all tasks, some might be far away, some might not be having the right skills, and others might already busy with other service jobs assigned previously. so based on the below points we can perform the intelligent filtering.

  • What the job needs (Like skills, tools, etc.)
  • Which technicians are available to perform the service task
  • Who is nearby to perform the service task
  • Who has done the similar job well previously.

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • Lesser time consumption: No need to manually check the list of all customers.
  • Reduced errors: Selects only technicians who are qualified and are available.
  • Improved customer service: Faster and better matches which results in the quicker resolutions for the tasks.


Steps to Enable:

  1. Raise an Incident:
    • Go to your SAP support portal.
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI.
    • Mention that you have a valid license and want to activate Intelligent Filtering.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature:
    • Once the request is processed, SAP will activate the feature in your FSM environment.
  3. Verify in the FSM Portal:
    • Navigate to the Planning & Dispatching module.
    • You‚Äôll see technician suggestions ranked intelligently when assigning service calls.

Compared to the older Best Matching Technician plugin, Intelligent Filtering is smarter and much easier to use. The old plugin works based on business rules which has been set up for every company, like checking technician skills or distance. whereas Intelligent Filtering in FSM uses the AI to understand what exactly dispatcher is looking for in the technicians and it automatically suggests the best technicians available for the service task.  It is much faster, that means it supports natural language searches. And it also gives the extra insights like past equipment history (which is not available in the old plugin doesn‚Äôt offer).


-> Assignment Duration Prediction:

Assignment Duration Prediction can be seen during the dispatching of an activity which will provide the overview like how long it will take to complete the current service task, which technician will be suitable for this activity rather than dispatcher guessing how long it might take to complete the current service tasks.

It uses the data like below:

  • The type of service task which needs to be assigned
  • The technician‚Äôs past performance on the service tasks
  • Historical data which are similar to the current service task
  • Job priority and some other requirements

This will help the dispatchers to plan accurately and helps to avoid the delay.

 Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  •  Better scheduling: can avoid the overloading the technicians.
  • Lesser delays during the assignment of service tasks.

Steps to Enable:

  1. Training the (AI Model) system

You can do this in two easy ways:

  • Option A: Use the Settings Screen
    • Go to Settings and Configuration in FSM.
    • Click on Assignment Duration Prediction.
    • Select your training data and click Train.

 

  • Option B: Use a Sample Business Rule
    • Download the sample rule from SAP Help.
    • Upload it to your FSM system.
    • Add your technical contact and adjust the date range if needed.
    • Run the rule to train the model.
  1. Activate the Feature
  • Go to: Settings and Configuration ‚Üí Planning and Dispatching ‚Üí General Settings ‚Üí Activity Planning ‚Üí Additional Settings
  • Turn on the checkbox:
    ‚ÄúAllow assignment duration prediction for semi and fully automated scheduling‚Äù
  1. Start Using It
  • Use features like Auto-Scheduling or Best Matching Technician.
  • The system will now use predicted durations instead of planned ones when assigning jobs.

 

-> Activity Summary:

Activity summary is like an assistant who give you the overview of the activity like what technician was doing, it gives you the summarized explanation of activity in detail, it helps the dispatcher to understand the below points:

  • what types of jobs were completed by technicians?
  • how much time did they take to complete the activity?
  • Did any issue occur during the completion of activity?


Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • with the help of activity summary dispatcher can save time as he doesn't have to go through each and every activity
  • Dispatcher can quickly understand how team is performing the activity using this feature
  • Can quickly identify if there is any issue which is occurring multiple times
  • Better decisions could be made with the help of summaries


 Steps to Enable

  1. Raise a Support Request
    • Go to the SAP Support Portal
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI
    • Mention that you want to enable Activity Summary along with other features.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature
    • Once approved, SAP will activate it in your FSM system
  3. Check in the FSM Portal
    • Go to the Planning and Dispatching module
    • You‚Äôll see AI-generated summaries for completed jobs

 

-> Equipment Summary:

Equipment Summary is similar to activity summary where in the activity summary we will be getting the summary of the completed activity but in the equipment summary we will be getting the summary of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks. it provides the details of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks which will help the dispatcher to make better decisions like.

  • Dispatcher can see which equipment was used for which service activity
  • how often did technician used this equipment
  • if there is any issue related to this equipment that can be seen in the equipment summary along with that, we can also see the performance of the equipment over time

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • it saves time by giving the summary of the equipment in an instance rather than going through the equipment history record
  • if there is any reoccurring issue that can be fixed with the help of this feature so it will be very useful for preventive maintenance activities


Steps to Enable:

  1. Go to Planning and Dispatching - Open the Planning and Dispatching module in FSM.
  2. Open a Service Call you can either click on a service call from the Dispatching Board or select one from the Service Calls list.
  3. Generate Equipment Summary
    • Inside the service call, go to the General Information tab.
    • Scroll down to the Insights section.
    • Click the button to generate the equipment summary.
  4. Review and Use the Summary
    • The system will show a short, AI-generated summary of the equipment‚Äôs history.

 

 

Conclusion:

SAP FSM‚Äôs AI features help the service teams to work much faster and smarter by reducing the manual effort and better decision making.

entry.title: Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP
entry.content:
Introduction

When you start learning CAP, running cds add tiny-sample generates all the necessary sample artifacts, including a CSV file inside the db/data folder. Once deployed, the data from this CSV file is loaded as initial data into SAP HANA Cloud.

This mechanism seems convenient for loading initial data into SAP HANA Cloud for productive applications, doesn‚Äôt it?
However, there‚Äôs a catch. If you change the CSV data or modify the schema, the data in SAP HANA Cloud will be reinitialized with the CSV content ‚Äî including the data entered by users! Let‚Äôs take a look at what the documentation says:

On SAP HANA, only use CSV files for configuration data that can't be changed by application users. ‚Üí See CSV data gets overridden in the SAP HANA guide for details.

This is exactly the point I want to highlight in this article. At the same time, I‚Äôve also explored some alternative approaches and validated them.

 

Case1: New Development

When developing a new CAP application, you have the following options:

  • Option A: Do not use CSV files to register initial data for tables that will be maintained by the application.
  • Option B: If both initial data and user-generated data need to coexist, define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata file.

Option A is the simplest, if feasible. However, in some cases ‚Äî such as for master data ‚Äî the ability to quickly load initial data from CSV files is attractive. Below, let‚Äôs look at Option B in more detail.

 

Option B: Define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata

1. Add a column called dataCategory to the CSV file to distinguish between different types of data. (This is just an example; you can use any column as in identifier.) 

entity Books {
  key ID    : Integer;
      title : String;
      stock : Integer;
      dataCategory: String enum {
        system = 'S';
        user = 'U';
      }
}

2. Run the command cds build --production to generate an .hdbtabledata file in the gen/db/src/data folder. Copy this file to the db/src/static/csv folder, and then add an include_filter as shown below.  This ensures that the HDI container takes ownership only of the records specified by the filter. (Note: The values must be strings, even if the column‚Äôs data type is numeric.)

{
  "format_version": 1,
  "imports": [
    {
      ...,
      "import_settings": {
        "import_columns": [
          "ID",
          "TITLE",
          "STOCK",
          "DATACATEGORY"
        ],
        "include_filter": [
          { "DATACATEGORY" : "S" }
        ]
      },
      "column_mappings": {
        "ID": "ID",
        "TITLE": "title",
        "STOCK": "stock",
        "DATACATEGORY": "dataCategory"
      }
    }
  ]
}

3. Move the CSV file into the db/src/static/csv folder as well. Don't forget to set the dataCategory to "S".

ID,title,stock,dataCategory
1,Wuthering Heights,100,S
2,Jane Eyre,500,S

4. After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state (as shown in the result of a GET request):

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. When schema changes or updates to the initial data are applied, records with dataCategory = "S" are overwritten, while records with dataCategory = "U" remain untouched. For example, after adding a new column newField:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 100, "title": "Wuthering Heights" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "newField": null, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Case 2: Accidentally Mixed Data

In some cases, custom data and pre-delivered data (from a CSV file) may accidentally end up in the same table governed by an HDI Table Data artifact (.hdbtabledata) without filter conditions to separate them. 

SAP Note 2922271 outlines how to handle this situation. Below, I‚Äôll walk you through the steps.

Note: The procedure described here applies to single-tenant applications. For multitenant scenarios, please refer to the documentation, as well as @Sekar_Somasundaram's  detailed blog post. 

 

Steps at a Glance

  • Delete the CSV file.
  • Make the .hdbtabledata artifact subject to undeploy.
  • Ensure that existing data is preserved during undeploy.

 

Current State of the Data

  • The CSV file initially contains the following data:

ID,title,stock
1,Wuthering Heights,100
2,Jane Eyre,500

  • After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Step-by-Step: Deleting the CSV File After Initial Deployment

1. Delete the CSV file.

2. Add "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata" to db/undeploy.json as shown below:

[
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbindex",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbconstraint",
  "src/gen/**/*_drafts.hdbtable",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbcalculationview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata"
]

3. Copy gen/db/package.json to the db folder, and add the following parameters to the start script.

 --undeploy src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true

In my example, the package.json looks as follows:

{
  "name": "deploy",
  "dependencies": {
    "hdb": "^0",
    "@sap/hdi-deploy": "^5"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=18"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node node_modules/@sap/hdi-deploy/deploy.js --use-hdb --parameter com.sap.hana.di.table/try_fast_table_migration=true --undeploy src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true"
  }
}

4. Deploy the project. In the db-deployer log, you will see a message indicating that the existing data was not deleted.

[APP/TASK/deploy/0] OUT The "skip_data_deletion" make parameter is set; no data will be deleted from the target table "MY_BOOKSHOP_BOOKS"

As a result, the updated user data remains intact.

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. Before the next deployment, delete the db/package.json file to restore the original state. From this point on, even if the schema changes, the data will no longer be overridden.

 

Other Ways to Register Data

Besides using CSV files during deployment, you can load data through the following approaches as well:

  • Insert data via HTTP requests: Insert data after deployment using HTTP requests.
  • Upload CSV files through the Database Explorer: Upload CSV files directly from the Database Explorer.
  • For local testing: Place CSV files in the test/data folder instead of db/data (see: Location of CSV Files | CAPire).

 

Closing

A clear strategy on how to provide initial data must be defined upfront. CSV files are convenient but must be used with caution, particularly in productive environments. Applying best practices such as separating system and user data, leveraging .hdbtabledata filters, or considering alternative loading options will help maintain data integrity and protect user input across deployments.

 

References

  • CSV Data Gets Overridden (capire) 
  • I removed sample data (.csv file) from my project. Still, the data is deployed and overwrites existing data. (capire)

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #3 in the Series
entry.content:
Welcome back to my blog series on the value of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In the first two blogs, I discussed how features such as multi-model engines, infrastructure independence, and a next-generation application foundation all can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

In fact, we‚Äôve already seen powerful confirmation of the value of this database. For example, global consulting services provider CONTAX Inc. migrated to SAP HANA Cloud to gain the elasticity and scalability it needed to handle huge demands on its database resources. This modernization helped CONTAX expand its database capacity while reducing its overall memory footprint and cost by 25%.

That‚Äôs impressive. So how can you best estimate the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud for your enterprise?

Many organizations want to migrate their database to the cloud because they want to build and deploy intelligent applications at scale. But that requires an advanced data landscape architecture‚Äîa database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for modernizing your applications. Let‚Äôs talk about two capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud that help you meet that need and deliver exceptional value: intelligent data tiering and multi-dimensional elastic scalability.

Intelligent data tiering

The exploding growth of business data is both a cost issue and a management challenge for your business. How can you store the data users need and make it easily accessible without busting the budget?

Traditional database technology requires that you choose between database performance and costs. Should you pay more to over-provision storage space so data can be easily persisted in case of growing demands? Or should you archive data to save money but make data harder to access?

With SAP HANA Cloud, you can strike the right balance for your business.

 Intelligent, multi-temperature data management features help you store data in tiers according to type, operational usefulness, access frequency, and scalability requirements. The database locates frequently accessed, business-critical ‚Äúhot‚Äù data in high-performance, in-memory storage, which facilitates real-time processing. ‚ÄúWarm‚Äù data requiring moderate access uses disk storage. Infrequently accessed ‚Äúcold‚Äù data can be stored in a lower-cost data lake optimized for long-term retention and compliance.

By combining tiered storage with advanced virtualization capabilities, SAP HANA Cloud reduces cost and complexity while enabling optimum overall performance. Applications and users can query data at any tier without needing to know where the data is stored. Automatic optimization based on data location and access patterns eliminates complex, costly ETL processes‚Äîwhile supporting both operational efficiency and analytical depth. Data tiering also simplifies application development by offering one interface to multiple data tiers. Developers can use that interface to query data for applications without needing to know where the data is stored.

A recent IDC study [1] assessed database performance impacts for organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Query speed and response time improved by 31% and 29%, respectively. Backups executed 27% faster. Both data load time and recovery time were 24% faster.

‚ÄúData is more accessible with SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù said one study participant. ‚ÄúIt is also available in real time and loads far quicker than our previous environment. Our data performance has enhanced.‚Äù

Multi-dimensional elastic scalability

Another way SAP HANA Cloud helps you balance performance and cost is by enabling elastic scalability for data processing and storage across multiple dimensions. In today‚Äôs dynamic database environments, short-term processing peaks caused by issues such as period-end reporting surges, seasonal transactions, or heavy analytics workloads can create havoc.

Elastic scalability lets you adjust compute and storage resources based on workload demands, in real time. The database ramps up resources during periods of high demand and then reduces them during low-usage times to conserve costs. Flexible resources include:

  • Performance classes, with flexible CPUs and memory ratios
  • Elastic compute nodes, on-demand resources provisioned in minutes for data-intensive OLAP workloads
  • Dynamic scalability, with individual storage tiers that allow the database to grow or shrink as needed

SAP HANA Cloud also includes elasticity features such as class-based dynamic workload routing, which automatically sends queries to the most appropriate compute resources. An ECN advisor analyzes historical workload patterns and creates optimal provisioning schedules. To prevent scaling events from disrupting application performance, SAP HANA Cloud offers built-in monitoring and workload routing capabilities.

These elastic scalability features help you respond rapidly to changing business needs, enabling optimal performance without over provisioning resources. These features make data more accessible to users while reducing infrastructure complexity. Together, they can help you drive operational agility and cost-effective resource management.

With these benefits in mind, IDC evaluated the infrastructure costs of surveyed companies that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Using its business value methodology, IDC concluded that the infrastructure costs of an SAP HANA Cloud environment were 20% less than a comparable database environment over a three-year period.

According to one study participant operating in the retail industry, ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud has given my organization the ability to scale and reduce redundancy, which are significant benefits.‚Äù

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the next blog to learn how native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines database administrator duties can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

 [1] ‚ÄúThe Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.
